source.name: City of Toronto / Circular Materials
source.notes: Based on official City of Toronto blue bin guidelines. As of Jan 2026, recycling managed by Circular Materials. Expanded materials accepted including coffee cups, K-Cup pods, and black plastic.

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
notes: Lids must be removed from glass bottles and jars
As of Jan 2026 managed by Circular Materials: 1-888-921-2686 or circularmaterials.ca/toronto
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass; wrap in newspaper and place in garbage
Don't include window glass, mirrors, or drinking glasses

materials.name: Rigid plastic food jars and tubs
notes: Lids stay on for rigid plastic food jars and tubs
commonMistakes: Don't include non-food plastic containers like flower pots

materials.name: Clear plastic food containers and clamshells
notes: Clear clamshell-style containers accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include foam containers

materials.name: Disposable plastic cups
notes: Rigid disposable cups only; no foam
commonMistakes: Don't include foam or styrofoam cups

materials.name: Plastic beverage bottles
notes: Lids stay on for beverage bottles
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still in them

materials.name: Detergent, soap, and shampoo bottles
instructions: Leave lids, sprayers, and pumps ON
notes: All pumps, sprayers, and lids can stay attached
commonMistakes: Don't remove pumps or sprayers; leave them on

materials.name: Clear CD and DVD cases
instructions: Place clear case in blue bin
notes: Only clear cases accepted; not coloured ones
commonMistakes: Don't include the actual disc; take to e-waste

materials.name: Black plastic containers
notes: NEW in 2026: black plastic containers are now accepted in Toronto's blue bin
commonMistakes: Previously not accepted; now OK as of 2026

materials.name: Frozen juice cups
notes: NEW in 2026: frozen juice cups now accepted
commonMistakes: Previously not accepted; now OK as of 2026

materials.name: Ice cream tubs
notes: NEW in 2026: ice cream tubs now accepted
commonMistakes: Previously not accepted; now OK as of 2026

materials.name: Toothpaste tubes
instructions: Squeeze out as much product as possible
notes: NEW in 2026: toothpaste tubes now accepted
commonMistakes: Previously not accepted; now OK as of 2026

materials.name: Deodorant containers
instructions: Empty as much product as possible
notes: NEW in 2026: deodorant containers now accepted
commonMistakes: Previously not accepted; now OK as of 2026

materials.name: Coffee cups (paper, lined)
notes: NEW in 2026: lined paper coffee cups now accepted in Toronto's blue bin
This is a major change; previously they went to garbage
commonMistakes: Don't put in green bin; they now go in blue bin in Toronto

materials.name: K-Cup pods
instructions: Empty the coffee grounds (compost them in green bin)
Place empty #5 PP pod in blue bin
notes: NEW in 2026: K-Cup pods (#5 PP) now accepted once emptied
Must be #5 polypropylene
commonMistakes: Must empty grounds first; grounds go in green bin
Only #5 PP pods accepted

materials.name: Food cans
notes: Steel and tin cans accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Beverage cans
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't crush cans

materials.name: Aluminum foil and trays
notes: Must be clean; heavily soiled foil goes in garbage
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil covered in baked-on food

materials.name: Empty aerosol cans
notes: Non-empty aerosols are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized; take to household hazardous waste depot

materials.name: Newspapers
notes: Do not bag in plastic
commonMistakes: Don't put wet or soiled newspapers in blue bin; those go in green bin

materials.name: Magazines and catalogues
notes: Glossy paper is accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic-wrapped magazines without removing wrap

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Cut large pieces to fit in or beside blue bin
notes: Clean cardboard only; food-soiled cardboard goes in green bin
commonMistakes: Don't include wax-coated cardboard
Food-soiled cardboard goes in green bin

materials.name: Office paper and printer paper
notes: Shredded paper should be placed in a paper bag before blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't include laminated paper

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten and place in blue bin
notes: Clean paper bags only
commonMistakes: Food-soiled paper bags go in green bin

materials.name: Milk and juice cartons
notes: Gable-top and aseptic cartons both accepted
commonMistakes: Don't flatten; leave in 3D shape for sorting

materials.name: Plastic plant pots
instructions: Rinse and place in blue bin
notes: Rigid plastic plant pots accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include ceramic or terracotta pots

materials.name: Food waste (all types)
instructions: Use a green bin liner or newspaper to wrap
All food accepted: meat, dairy, bones, fish, fruit, vegetables
notes: Toronto green bin accepts all food waste including meat and dairy
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in garbage or blue bin
Don't use plastic bags as liners; use certified compostable liners or newspaper

materials.name: Diapers and sanitary products
instructions: Toronto accepts diapers and sanitary products in green bin
notes: This is unique to Toronto; many cities put these in garbage
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage; Toronto's green bin program accepts them

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag in newspaper or certified compostable bag
notes: Toronto green bin accepts pet waste including cat litter
commonMistakes: Don't use plastic bags; use paper or compostable bags

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
notes: Food-soiled paper and cardboard go in green bin, not blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put soiled paper in blue bin; it contaminates recycling

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in green bin or yard waste bags
Branches: cut to 3 feet, bundle, and place beside green bin
notes: Yard waste collection seasonal; check toronto.ca for dates
commonMistakes: Don't use plastic bags for yard waste

materials.name: Compostable plastics
instructions: Compostable plastics are NOT accepted in Toronto's blue bin OR green bin
notes: Despite being labelled 'compostable', these go in garbage in Toronto
They contaminate both recycling and organic streams
commonMistakes: Don't put in green bin or blue bin; garbage only
Labels like 'compostable' or 'biodegradable' are misleading for Toronto bins

materials.name: Plastic bags and film
instructions: Do NOT put in blue bin
Some retailers accept clean bags for store drop-off
notes: Plastic bags jam recycling machinery
Bag-to-bag recycling available at many grocery stores
commonMistakes: Never put plastic bags in blue bin
Never use plastic bags to bag recyclables

materials.name: Styrofoam / polystyrene
notes: Toronto does not accept styrofoam in curbside recycling
Some depots accept clean styrofoam; check toronto.ca/wastewizard
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin

materials.name: Chip bags and snack pouches
notes: The metallic lining prevents recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin

materials.name: Candy wrappers
notes: Mixed metallized film; not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin or green bin

materials.name: Receipts (thermal)
instructions: Thermal paper contains BPA; not recyclable
notes: Regular paper receipts (non-shiny) can go in blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't put thermal receipts in blue bin

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to a Community Environment Day or household hazardous waste depot
Tape terminals of 9V and lithium batteries
Many retailers accept batteries (Canadian Tire, Best Buy, Home Depot)
notes: Batteries cause fires in garbage and recycling trucks
Toronto has drop-off locations across the city
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage or blue bin
Tape exposed terminals to prevent fire

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to a Community Environment Day or municipal drop-off depot
Ontario Electronic Stewardship locations accept e-waste
notes: E-waste contains valuable recoverable materials
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage or blue bin

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to a Community Environment Day or household hazardous waste depot
Dried latex paint (in can with lid off) can go in garbage
notes: Toronto runs Community Environment Days several times per year
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drain
Don't put liquid paint in garbage

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Most Shoppers Drug Mart and Rexall locations accept medications
notes: Ontario has a free pharmaceutical take-back program
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill, Value Village, or Salvation Army
Worn-out textiles accepted at some bins
notes: Toronto has many clothing donation options
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin or garbage if reusable

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to household hazardous waste depot
LED and incandescent: wrap and place in garbage
notes: CFL bulbs contain mercury
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL or fluorescent bulbs in garbage

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to household hazardous waste depot
Some Canadian Tire and auto shops accept used oil
notes: Never pour down drain or into soil
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drain

materials.name: Propane tanks and cylinders
instructions: Take to household hazardous waste depot
notes: Pressurized containers are dangerous in garbage trucks
commonMistakes: Never puncture or put in garbage

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Small amounts: pour onto newspaper or paper towel and place in green bin
Large amounts: take to household hazardous waste depot
notes: Never pour down the drain
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink; causes sewer blockages

materials.name: Books
instructions: If damaged, place in blue bin
notes: Toronto Public Library accepts book donations
Donating is preferred over recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in garbage

materials.name: Cereal and food boxes
instructions: Flatten and place in blue bin
notes: Clean paperboard is recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic liner inside the box

materials.name: Egg cartons
notes: Only paper-based egg cartons are recyclable
commonMistakes: Styrofoam cartons go in garbage, not blue bin

materials.name: Metal lids and caps
instructions: Or place inside a steel can and crimp closed
notes: Small metal items can fall through sorting screens
commonMistakes: Don't attach to glass; remove and recycle separately

materials.name: Wax paper and parchment paper
instructions: Not recyclable or compostable in Toronto
notes: Wax coating prevents recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin or green bin

materials.name: Bubble wrap and packing film
instructions: Some retailers accept clean plastic film for store drop-off
notes: Plastic film jams recycling equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin

materials.name: Mirrors, ceramics, and drinking glasses
notes: Different melting point than bottle glass; contaminates glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin; they are not the same as bottle glass

materials.name: Needles and sharps
instructions: Place in a puncture-resistant container (e.g., detergent bottle)
Take to a pharmacy or Community Environment Day
notes: Never put loose sharps in any bin
commonMistakes: Never put in garbage, blue bin, or green bin

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule a special curbside collection through toronto.ca
Or take to a Community Environment Day or transfer station
notes: Fee may apply
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling pickup

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Most shops accept old tires when purchasing new ones
Or take to Community Environment Day
notes: Ontario Tire Stewardship handles recycling
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: If heavily soiled with grease: green bin
notes: In Toronto, greasy pizza boxes go in green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy pizza boxes in blue bin

materials.name: Plastic cutlery
notes: Too small and lightweight for recycling sorting equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin

materials.name: Plastic straws
notes: Too small for recycling equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin

materials.name: Toothbrush
notes: Mixed materials; not recyclable curbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
notes: All fruit and fruit scraps go in green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
notes: All vegetable scraps go in green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Wrap in newspaper or paper bag
notes: Toronto green bin accepts all meat and bones
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Dairy products
notes: Expired dairy food goes in green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage
Recycle the container separately in blue bin

materials.name: Coffee grounds and filters
instructions: Place grounds and paper filter in green bin
notes: Great compost material
commonMistakes: K-Cup pods go in blue bin (emptied); grounds go in green bin

materials.name: Spray bottles (plastic)
notes: Spray triggers and pumps stay on in Toronto
commonMistakes: Don't remove the sprayer

recycle: Rigid plastic food jars and tubs (lids on)
Clear plastic clamshells and food containers
Detergent, soap, and shampoo bottles (lids/pumps/sprayers on)
Ice cream tubs and frozen juice cups (NEW 2026)
compost: All food waste (meat, dairy, bones, fruit, vegetables)
Food-soiled paper (pizza boxes, napkins, paper towels)
trash: Compostable plastics (NOT accepted in green or blue bin)

compost: Plastic of any kind (including compostable plastics)

tips: As of Jan 2026, Toronto recycling is managed by Circular Materials. Contact: 1-888-921-2686 or circularmaterials.ca/toronto
NEW 2026: coffee cups, K-Cup pods, black plastic, toothpaste tubes, deodorant containers, ice cream tubs now accepted in blue bin
Lids OFF for glass; lids ON for plastic bottles and containers
Compostable plastics go in GARBAGE â€” not blue bin or green bin
Diapers and pet waste go in the GREEN bin in Toronto
Use Toronto's Waste Wizard at toronto.ca/wastewizard for item-specific guidance

locations.name: City of Toronto Transfer Stations
locations.notes: Multiple locations across Toronto; check website for nearest depot

locations.name: Circular Materials Toronto
locations.notes: Manages Toronto's blue bin recycling program as of January 2026
